title: 111_hr3694
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Removing Excess Litigation Involving Energy on Federal Lands Act" or the "RELIEF Act." Congress finds that the US spends over $1 billion daily on importing crude oil, the largest wealth transfer in history. The US has significant oil and natural gas reserves in the outer Continental Shelf. Environmental groups have legally challenged leases in Alaska, delaying energy resources reaching the public at a high cost to the economy. Congress finds expedited judicial review necessary to prevent abuse of the US judicial system in relation to challenges delaying energy resources reaching the public and impacting the American economy. Exclusive jurisdiction over causes and claims related to covered energy projects is granted to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. All causes and claims must be filed within 60 days of the action or decision by a Federal official, or they will be barred. SEC. 5. DISTRICT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA DEADLINE.

All proceedings subject to section 3 must be resolved within 180 days of filing and take precedence over other matters. Failure to meet the deadline results in dismissal with prejudice.

SEC. 6. ABILITY TO SEEK APPELLATE REVIEW.

Only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court.

SEC. 7. DEADLINE FOR APPEAL TO THE SUPREME COURT. SEC. 7. DEADLINE FOR APPEAL TO THE SUPREME COURT. If a writ of certiorari is granted by the Supreme Court, the district court's judgment must be resolved within 180 days. All proceedings take precedence over other matters before the Supreme Court. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON SCOPE OF REVIEW AND RELIEF. Judicial review of Federal actions under this Act presumes administrative findings correct unless proven otherwise. Prospective relief can only be granted if narrowly drawn and least intrusive. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. SEC. 9. LEGAL FEES. Any person filing a petition for judicial review under this Act must pay prevailing parties' fees unless the Court finds their position justified. SEC. 10. EXCLUSION. This Act does not apply to disputes between lease parties. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. SEC. 11. COVERED ENERGY PROJECT DEFINED. A covered energy project refers to actions or decisions by Federal officials regarding leasing Federal lands for energy exploration, development, production, processing, or transmission, including actions under such leases.
